text: The outbreak of the COVID-19 pandemic in the spring of 2020 witnesses two significant changes in the U.S. stock market. First, large negative shocks brought by the pandemic significantly reduce market returns by 13.3% in March, while market uncertainty measured by VIX shot up from 18% to 83%, and market liquidity quickly worsens, with effective spread quadruples at the same time. Lessons from previous crisis periods show that the smooth functioning of the capital market during these difficult times is extremely important. Second, retail investorsâ€™ involvement in the U.S. stock market significantly increases after the pandemic starts. Here we identify the marketable retail order flow using the algorithm in Boehmer, Jones, Zhang and Zhang (2021, BJZZ hereafter), and find the monthly aggregate marketable retail trading volumes more than double from $325 billion in December of 2019 to $852 billion in September 2020, and remain high at around $700 billion for the next two years. Many attributes the rise of retail trading to the introduction of retail-oriented investing platforms with zero trading commissions, such as Robinhood, which attract young and unexperienced individual investors, with relatively little wealth but are incentivized to develop investing expertise by actually trading.1 Given the substantial negative shocks brought by pandemic, the significant surges in retail trading and the new mix of investors, do retail investors contribute positively towards price discovery, market volatility and liquidity, when these market qualities are the most needed? text: Earlier works provide mixed theoretical predictions and empirical evidence for the above important question. Given the large volumes of existing work, we separate these studies into three broad groups. We refer to group I as the â€œpure noise retail investors hypothesisâ€. Classical papers, such as Black (1986), assume that pure noise traders have no information regarding firm value. If retail investors are pure noise traders, they canâ€™t predict future price movements and canâ€™t contribute to price discovery, yet their trading provides liquidity and improves market quality, as in Glosten and Milgrom (1985) and Kyle (1985). Group II contains works consistent with the â€œinformed retail investors hypothesisâ€. Kelley and Tetlock (2013) find evidence that marketable retail investors are informed about future firm fundamentals and their trading shows return predictability. If retail investors are informed, their trades demand liquidity from other market participants, which would increase transaction costs, and reduce market quality. That is, our study focuses on how retail investors in general, rather than only Robinhood investors, contribute to the price discovery process and market quality measures during the special period of pandemic. Specifically, we answer three research questions: how the new mix of retail investors contributes to price discovery and market quality; how other market participants, such as short-sellers and high frequency traders, respond to the increased retail trading; and finally, how these findings are related to the three groups of hypotheses. We start by investigating how retail order flows during this period are related to future stock price movements in the cross section. BJZZ examine the U.S. equity market between 2010 and 2015 and find that the signed marketable retail order flows, or retail order imbalances (buys minus sells), can predict future stock returns positively and significantly, indicating that retail marketable orders contain price-relevant information that is not yet incorporated into prices. On the other hand, the new entrants of retail investors, mostly Robinhood-type, are less experienced and more susceptible to trading biases, and might make suboptimal investment choices. Using a sample period between January 2020 and March 2022, we show that the more generally representative retail order imbalances still positively and significantly predict future daily returns in the cross section. Economically, an interquartile increase in retail order imbalance is associated with 3.90 bps of higher return for the next day (9.75% annualized), which is highly statistically significant. The predictive pattern persists for the next twelve weeks and is robust across firms with different sizes and different turnover ratios. That is, the higher uncertainty during pandemic and the arrival of more inexperienced retail investors do not diminish the positive predictive pattern of the general retail trading for future stock returns. This might not be too surprising because Robinhood investors only account for a small part of the general retail order flows. Here we focus on two groups of relatively sophisticated investors: high frequency traders (HFT) and short-sellers (SS). High frequency traders are generally believed to trade on arbitrage opportunities and are sensitive to short-term changes in prices and liquidity, while short-sellers are assumed to be informed pessimistic investors who collect and process information regarding future price movements. The general activity levels of retail investors are associated with significantly lower activity levels of both HFTs and SSâ€™s. text: Our paper contributes to the debate on how retail investor trading contributes towards price discovery and market quality.4 As mentioned before, there have been many studies providing mixed theoretical predictions and empirical evidence. As for price discovery, while Kaniel et al. (2008), Kelley and Tetlock (2013), Barrort et al. (2016) and Boehmer et al. (2021) find retail order imbalances positively predict stock returns, some papers find retail trading lose money (Barber and Odean (2000, 2008)). Recent studies focus on Robinhood investors during the covid, but the results are still mixed: Welch (2022) show that the aggregated crowd consensus portfolio has good timing and good alpha, while Barber et al. (2022) find that Robinhood investors engage in more attention-induced trading and results in negative returns. As for market quality, for instance, among recent influential papers, though Barrot et al. (2016) and Ozik et al. (2021) find retail investors provide liquidity especially in volatile market, Eaton et al. (2022) show decreased Robinhood participation associated with higher market liquidity. In comparison with the existing studies, our paper examines the 2+ years of pandemic period and a much larger retail population, which provides a more general perspective on retailâ€™s influences on price discovery and market quality during an important crisis period, and helps us possibly examine a more general nature of retail investors. Our main empirical findings, retail order flow positively predicts return, retail trading reduces liquidity, increases volatility and reduces sophisticated investorsâ€™ participation during pandemic, help to separate retail investors from pure noise traders. Our additional findings that retail order flows predict long-run returns and long-run earnings news help us to discover the informed retail investors. Alternative Retail Identification Algorithms in Barber et al. (2023) Barber, Huang, Jorion, Odean, Schwarz (2023, BHJOS hereafter) propose two alternative variations to improve the signing accuracy of retail buys/sells beyond Boehmer, Jones, Zhang, and Zhang (2021, BJZZ hereafter)â€™s algorithm. In the first variation, the first step to identify retail trades is identical to that proposed in BJZZ, but BHJOS change how the trades are signed as buy or sell. To be specific, they first identify retail as all trades that are executed at subpenny except those between [$0.004, $0.006]. Trades are then signed using the midpoint of the NBBO. Trades that are executed at prices below the midpoint are signed as retail sell, while those above the midpoint are signed as retail buy. In the second variation, BHJOS change both the identification and signing of retail trades. To be specific, retail trades are identified as all trades that are executed at a subpenny except those that are executed between 40 and 60 percent of the NBBO spread. Trades are then signed using the quote midpoint rule described in first variation. Our sample period is January 2020 to March 2022, and our sample firms are all common stocks listed on U.S. stock exchanges with a share price of at least $1.
